importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article highlights the current status of humanitarian aid to Gaza, reflecting the ongoing crisis and the urgency of delivering food supplies after the US-brokered ceasefire.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period around the ceasefire agreement and the immediate aftermath indicates a critical window for humanitarian access and aid delivery in Gaza.

keyTakeAways: Food supplies to Gaza remain significantly below the WFP's daily target of 2,000 tonnes, with only 750 metric tonnes entering daily.
Only two Israeli-controlled crossings—Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara—are currently operational, severely limiting aid flow.
The WFP has opened 26 food distribution points in Gaza, up from five, but still far short of the 145 it aims to operate across the territory.
Humanitarian aid has reached northern Gaza via southern routes, but large-scale convoys to Gaza City or the north have not yet occurred.
The WFP has not been granted access to the Salah al-Din Street, a key corridor in northern Gaza, blocking full distribution.
Many Palestinians are storing food due to fear of supply disruptions, indicating ongoing instability and lack of confidence in the ceasefire’s longevity.
Hamas has committed to handing over 13 of 28 deceased captives’ bodies, with two more to be delivered by 18:00 GMT on 21 October 2025.
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu maintains the Rafah crossing remains closed until Hamas delivers more bodies.
The US-brokered ceasefire and Donald Trump’s 20-point plan are central to enabling full humanitarian access and aid delivery.
The WFP stresses that opening all border crossings is vital to achieving its goal of feeding half a million people for two weeks.

namedEntities.name: UN World Food Programme (WFP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A United Nations agency responsible for coordinating global food aid distribution.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP is the primary actor reporting on food supply levels and calling for increased aid access in Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Gaza Strip
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian territory in the Middle East, currently under conflict and humanitarian crisis.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The focus of the article is on the dire food shortage and humanitarian access challenges within the Gaza Strip.

namedEntities.name: Karem Abu Salem
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli-controlled border crossing into Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One of the two currently operational crossings through which food enters Gaza, limiting supply volume.

namedEntities.name: al-Karara (Kissufim)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli-controlled border crossing into Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The second operational crossing into Gaza, used for food deliveries and humanitarian access.

namedEntities.name: Salah al-Din Street
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major north-south street in Gaza, currently blocked to WFP access.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The street is a key corridor for aid to northern Gaza, but access has been denied due to security concerns.

namedEntities.name: Rafah border crossing
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A crossing between Gaza and Egypt, currently closed.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The closure limits humanitarian access from Egypt and reduces the number of entry points into Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former US President who brokered a ceasefire and proposed a 20-point plan for Gaza.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His role in mediating the ceasefire and advocating for full aid delivery makes him central to the humanitarian situation.

namedEntities.name: Benjamin Netanyahu
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Israeli Prime Minister who maintains the Rafah crossing is closed.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His political stance directly affects access to humanitarian corridors and aid distribution.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Palestinian political and militant group, responsible for overseeing the return of captives’ bodies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas has committed to returning bodies of deceased captives, which is a condition for opening certain crossings and easing the ceasefire.

namedEntities.name: Qassam Brigades
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A militant wing of Hamas, responsible for announcing the delivery of captives’ bodies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They publicly confirmed the exhumation and delivery of two more Israeli captives' remains, fulfilling part of the ceasefire agreement.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The UN World Food Programme reports that food supplies to Gaza remain critically low, with only 750 metric tonnes entering daily—far below the target of 2,000 tonnes—due to only two border crossings being open. The WFP calls for all crossings, including Rafah and Salah al-Din Street, to be opened to ensure equitable and widespread aid delivery. The US-brokered ceasefire and Donald Trump’s 20-point plan are seen as essential for enabling full humanitarian access. Hamas has committed to returning 13 of 28 deceased captives’ bodies, with two more delivered as of 18:00 GMT on 21 October, and Israeli officials maintain the Rafah crossing remains closed. As a result, many Gazans are storing food due to fears of future supply disruptions, highlighting the fragile and unstable nature of the ceasefire.
title: WFP says food supplies to Gaza below targets, urges more crossings to open
